description: From Middle English [Term?], from Old French gambon (compare modern French jambon (“ham”)), from gambe (“leg”), from Late Latin *gamba, from Ancient Greek καμπή (kampḗ), from Proto-Indo-European *kamp- (“to bend; crooked”). Doublet of jamon.

entries.meaning: A cut of quick-cured pork leg.

verbs.description: gammon (third-person singular simple present gammons, present participle gammoning, simple past and past participle gammoned)

description: Probably a special use of Middle English gamen (“game”).

entries.meaning: (backgammon) A victory in backgammon achieved when the opponent has not borne off a single stone.

verbs.description: gammon (third-person singular simple present gammons, present participle gammoning, simple past and past participle gammoned)

entries.meaning: (backgammon) To beat by a gammon (without the opponent bearing off a stone).

description: Perhaps related to the first etymology, with reference to tying up a ham.

entries.meaning: (nautical) A rope fastening a bowsprit to the stem of a ship (usually called a gammoning).

verbs.description: gammon (third-person singular simple present gammons, present participle gammoning, simple past and past participle gammoned)

entries.meaning: To lash with ropes (on a ship).

description: Perhaps a special use of the word from etymology 2.

verbs.description: gammon (third-person singular simple present gammons, present participle gammoning, simple past and past participle gammoned)

entries.meaning: (colloquial, dated, transitive) To deceive; to lie plausibly to.

description: Gained popularity in 2017 (in the phrase "Great Wall of Gammon", likening the referents' rosy complexions to gammon (“ham, bacon”)), although the metaphor was in use earlier: the BBC points to a 2016 use of "gammon face". Not related to the "gammon tendency" in Dickens' Nicholas Nickleby, where the word means "nonsense".

entries.meaning: (neologism, informal, derogatory, UK) A middle-aged or older right-wing, reactionary white man, or such men collectively.
